SQL VERSIONS

SQL Standard Version Release Date
SQL-86 1986
SQL-89 1989
SQL-92 1992
SQL:1999 (SQL3) 1999
SQL:2003 2003
SQL:2006 2006
SQL:2008 2008
SQL:2011 2011
SQL:2016 2016
SQL:2019 2019
SQL:2023 2023
  • SQL-86: The first commercial implementation of SQL by Oracle.
  • SQL:1999 (SQL3): Introduced object-oriented features, triggers, and recursive queries.
  • SQL:2003: Added XML-related features, window functions, and standardized MERGE statements.
  • SQL:2006: Focused on XML integration enhancements.
  • SQL:2008: Introduced the TRUNCATE TABLE statement and improved diagnostics.
  • SQL:2011: Added temporal database features for handling historical data.
  • SQL:2016: Introduced JSON support and additional security features.
  • SQL:2019: Enhanced capabilities for big data and improved standardization.
  • SQL:2023: The latest updates include further enhancements to JSON support, performance optimizations, and expanded analytical functions.
  • Standards Development: The SQL standards are developed and maintained by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) and the International Electrotechnical Commission (IEC) under the joint ISO/IEC JTC 1/SC 32 committee.
  • Implementation Variations: While the SQL standard provides guidelines, different database management systems (DBMS) like MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQL Server, and Oracle may implement features differently or extend the standard with proprietary functionalities.

You can check if MySQL is installed on your system using the following methods depending on your operating system.

  1. On Windows / Linux / macOS
    mysql --version

  2. Ubuntu
    dpkg -l | grep mysql

  3. CentOS
    rpm -qa | grep mysql

If MySQL is installed, this will show the version.

For Exmple , my current mysql version shows like this :  mysql  Ver 8.0.33 for Win64 on x86_64 (MySQL Community Server - GPL)

MySQL CLI

MySQLi CLI (MySQL Improved Command-Line Interface) is a command-line client for MySQL. It's often used to interact with MySQL databases more securely and efficiently than the standard MySQL CLI.

To start the MySQLi CLI, use:

code
mysqli -u username -p

This connects you to the MySQL server, where you can execute SQL commands and queries.
